'''''Psilocybe hispanica''''' is a species of [[fungus]] in the family [[Hymenogastraceae]]. It produces small brown [[mushroom]]s with conical to convex [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] up to {{convert|10|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter and [[stipe (mycology)|stems]] {{convert|16|to|25|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|0.5|to|1|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} thick. Reported as new to science in 2000, it is only known from the [[Pyrenees]] mountain range in northern Spain and southwestern France, where it grows on horse dung in grass fields at elevations of {{convert|1700|to|2300|m|abbr=on}}. The mushroom contains the [[psychoactive]] compound [[psilocybin]]. The possible depiction of this species in the 6,000-year-old Selva Pascuala [[rock art]] suggests that it might have been used in ancient [[religious ritual]]s—the oldest evidence of such usage in prehistoric Europe.

==Taxonomy==
The species was described by Mexican mycologist [[Gastón Guzmán]] in a 2000 publication, based on specimens collected by Ignacio Seral Bozal near [[Huesca]] in northern Spain in 1995. ''Psilocybe hispanica'' is [[classification (biology)|classified]] in the [[section (biology)|section]] ''Semilanceata'' of the genus ''[[Psilocybe]]'' because of its thick-walled [[spore]]s and [[basidiocarp|fruit body]] that bruises blue with handling.<ref name=Guzman2000/> The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''hispanica'' is [[Latin language|Latin]] for "Spanish".<ref name=Cady2005/>

==Description==
The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] ranges in shape from somewhat conical to convex, and reaches diameters of {{convert|5|to|10|mm|in|1}}. Its surface is smooth, somewhat sticky to dry, and brown to brownish-yellow. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are somewhat [[adnation|adnate]], and brown-violaceous with whitish edges. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|16|to|25|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|0.5|to|1|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} thick, cylindrical, and slightly bulbous at the base. It is whitish-yellow, with [[wine (color)|vinaceous]] or blue-green to blackish tones towards the base. Mature specimens do not have a [[annulus (mycology)|veil]] on the stem. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is whitish, but like most psilocybin-containing species, stains blue when injured.<ref name=Guzman2000/>

The [[spore]]s are [[ellipsoid]] and measure 12–14.5 by 6.5–8 [[micrometre|μm]]. They have a brownish-yellow wall greater than 1 μm thick and a broad apical [[germ pore]] with an acute [[hilum (biology)|hilar appendix]] at the base (a region where the spore was once attached to the [[sterigma]]). The [[basidia]] (spore-bearing cells in the [[hymenium]]) are four-spored, [[hyaline]] (translucent), and measure 32–44 by 8–12 μm. The [[pileipellis|cap cuticle]] is made of a layer 130–150 μm thick, with hyaline, thin-walled gelatinized [[hypha]]e measuring 1.5–4 μm broad. The hypodermium (the tissue layer directly under the pileipellis) is made of thin-walled, hyaline hyphae, 2.5–8 μm broad, with a brownish incrusting [[pigment]]. [[Clamp connection]]s are present in the hyphae.<ref name=Guzman2000/>

''[[Psilocybe semilanceata]]'' is roughly similar in appearance to ''P. hispanica'', but may distinguished by its mycenoid (''[[Mycena]]''-like) appearance and acute [[umbo (mycology)|umbonate]] cap.<ref name=Guzman2000/> Although the grassland habitat of the two species is similar, ''P. semilanceata'' does not grow directly on dung; rather, it is a [[saprobic]] species that grows on decaying grass roots.<ref name=Keay1990/> ''[[Psilocybe fimetaria|P. fimetaria]]'' also resembles ''P. hispanica'', but it also has a mycenoid appearance and has a ring on the stem. In terms of microscopic characteristics, ''P. fimetaria'' has larger cheilocystidia that measure 20–32 by 4–8 μm. ''P. hispanica'' differs from ''[[Psilocybe liniformans|P. liniformans]]'' var. ''liniformans'' in that it lacks a gelatinous gill edge. [[Psilocybe liniformans var. americana|''P. liniformans'' var. ''americana'']] has larger cheilocystidia, measuring 22–33 by 5.5–9 μm, and it is known to grow only on soil around herbs, in the Northwest and Northeast USA and Chile.<ref name=Guzman2000/> ''[[Deconica coprophila]]'' (formerly known as ''Psilocybe coprophila'') is a [[little brown mushroom|small brownish mushroom]] that also grows on dung, but it does not contain psilocybin and does not have a bluing stem.<ref name="urlCalifornia Fungi: Psilocybe coprophila"/>

==Habitat and distribution==
''Psilocybe hispanica'' is a [[coprophilous fungus]] (dung-loving), and produces fruit bodies that grow solitarily or in dense groups on horse dung; sometimes more than 25 fruit bodies can arise from the same dung.<ref name=Guzman2003/> In Guzmán's original report, they were found in a Pyrenean meadow in [[Aragon]], at an elevation of {{convert|2300|m}}. In 2003, the species was reported from Tramacastillo de Tena, a small village in the Pyrenees; it was also reported to have "penetrated the French part of the Pyrenees". Within its restricted range, the mushroom is "very common" at altitudes of {{convert|1700|to|2300|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name=Guzman2003/>

==Uses==
The mushroom is consumed recreationally by Spanish youths for its [[psilocybin mushroom|mind-altering]] effects;<ref name=Guzman2003/><ref name=FernandezSasia2006/> other mushrooms used recreationally in Spain include ''P. semilanceata'' and ''[[Psilocybe gallaeciae|P. gallaeciae]]''.<ref name=Cole2006/> Guzmán and Castro report that a 17th-century medallion found in [[Tena Valley]] in the southern Pyrenees had images of a devil and mushrooms carved on it. The mushrooms—possibly either ''P. semilanceata'' or ''P. hispanica'', according to Guzmán and Castro—were used in [[witchcraft]], a common practice in the valley during the [[Middle Ages]].<ref name=Guzman2003/>

It has been argued that prehistoric rock art at a site known as Selva Pascuala near the Spanish town of [[Villar del Humo]] offers evidence that ''P. hispanica'' was used in [[religious ritual]]s 6,000 years ago. The [[rock shelter]] at Selva Pascuala was discovered in the early 20th century; in the early 21st century it was noticed that objects in one of the murals, which  previously had been described as "mushrooms", matched the general [[morphology (biology)|morphology]] of ''P. hispanica'': the mural depicts a row of 13 mushroom-like objects with convex to conical caps, and ringless stems that vary from straight to sinuous (wavy). Additionally, the mural shows a bull, which suggests an association with the coprophilic ''P. hispanica''. Although the hallucinogenic species ''P. semilanceata'' is also widespread in the area where the mural was found, its differing shape (narrowly conical and acutely [[papilla (mycology)|papillate]]) and its habitat on soil instead of dung suggests it is not the species represented in the mural. If the interpretation is correct, the mural represents the oldest evidence of psychedelic fungi use in Europe, and the third reported instance of rock art suggesting prehistoric usage of neurotropic fungi. The only older example is from [[Tassili n'Ajjer]], in the [[Sahara desert]] in southeast [[Algeria]]. In 1992, the Italian ethnobotanist [[Giorgio Samorini]] reported finding a painted mural dated 7000 to 9000 BCE portraying mushrooms,<ref name=Samorini1992/> later tentatively identified as ''[[Psilocybe mairei]]'', a species known from Algeria and [[Morocco]].<ref name=Akers2011/>
